text.text: What is Storytelling?

Stories are a rich information source that allow us to better understand the history and experiences of an individual or community. Storytelling can play an important role in planning, policy, education, and community recovery. In the context of crises and disasters, stories are a means by which information can be shared across generations and improve understanding of historical events or potential impacts.
What are stories?

Storytelling is a fundamental part of being human. We tell stories to communicate with our families and our neighbors. The information shared through stories can improve planning. Stories are narratives that persons have about their history and experiences that are intricately woven into their sense of identity [1]. Storytelling helps us to understand ourselves in the context of our surroundings and experiences, and how to navigate relationships and changes in complex and dynamic environments.
Why use storytelling?

The process of sharing stories functions to convey information, preserve culture, promote moral values, and increase empathy. Storytelling is a long-standing practice across many cultures and can be a vital tool for integrating diverse understandings and knowledge systems into formal planning processes. Incorporating storytelling can be as simple as allowing space for the sharing memories and experiences.
Incorporate storytelling into community processes to
• Provide critical information to understand the diverse experiences of specific events, inform how to address or anticipate future issues, and improve planning.
• Empower less powerful actors to be heard and new shared understandings to emerge through dialogue.
• Support community recovery by helping participants make sense of the past.
• Build empathy and understanding across and between groups within the community. [2, 3, 4]
Ethical considerations:
Storytelling sessions take an emotional toll on survivors and should be conducted in a way that minimizes dredging up suffering and trauma as much as possible. This requires adopting a
trauma-informed approach
when gathering this information. (Check out our resource on trauma-informed approaches to learn more.)

No one is entitled to a person’s story, and participants should not feel pressured or obligated to share their stories. When planning a storytelling activity, it is important to first ensure that the activity is appropriate and culturally sensitive, given the history of potential participants. For example, asking a person to revisit painful memories of past traumas may do more harm than good, particularly in a community that has been historically marginalized.
Storytelling can be used throughout the ERB process
to support trust and relationship building, develop empathy, and increase relevance of ERB indicators and actions to meet community needs.

Although planning involves dealing with the past, planning processes are about the future, as participants can imagine it. Stories that can be found in planning processes will contain explicit ideas for future events and the role of various actors in bringing them about. Storytelling should be connected to and have an impact on other activities such as policy, planning, or program implementation in order to make a difference [2].
Examples of storytelling and community recovery

• After the Disaster: Aftermath presents personal stories of resilience and recovery following recent flood and cyclone events in Australia, generated by community contributors and ABC Open producers.
https://www.abc.net.au/radio/programs/after-the-disaster/episodes
• The City of Everett, Washington incorporated storytelling into its
